greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of 4's in the last section of the set of partitions of n.
comment: Zero together with the first differences of A024788.
Also number of 4's in all partitions of n that do not contain 1 as a part.
a(n) is the number of partitions of n such that m(1) < m(3), where m = multiplicity; e.g., a(7) counts these 3 partitions: [4, 3], [3, 3, 1], [3, 2, 2]. - _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 01 2014
The last section of the set of partitions of n is also the n-th section of the set of partitions of any integer >= n. - _Omar E. Pol_, Apr 07 2014
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: It appears that A000041(n) = a(n+1) + a(n+2) + a(n+3) + a(n+4), n >= 0. - _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 04 2012
example: In the last section of the set of partitions of 8 the difference between the sum of the fourth column and the sum of the fifth column is 6 - 3 = 3 equaling the number of 4's, so a(8) = 3 (see also A024788).
maple: b:= proc(n, i) option remember; local g, h;
mathematica: z = 60; f[n_] := f[n] = IntegerPartitions[n]; t1 = Table[Count[f[n], p_ /; Count[p, 1] < Count[p, 3]], {n, 0, z}] (* _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 01 2014 *)
program: (Sage) A182714 = lambda n: sum(list(p).count(4) for p in Partitions(n) if 1 not in p)
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 13 2011
